advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.). <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMORY BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Vector Graphics also sold various cards for any S-100 systems. This one is a 8 Kb. static RAM card solded for $265 in kit version and $350 assembled.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The memory tool''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HOMO-COMPUTERUS</strong></font><br><blockquote>This image is from a brochure of a Dutch exhibition called "The office of the future" <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of the <b>Computer museum of the University of Amsterdam</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Really nice advert, we love it.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD. </strong></font><br><blockquote>The red part shows all the IBM-PC software boxes the VP could run.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advertisement for the HX-10D. If you can read japanese maybe you could tell us what's the difference with a HX-10...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMOTECH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST C-10 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983</blockquote>

computer.description:
The HP-65 is arguably the most elegant and classic pocket calculator ever built.
Boasting many firsts, including being the first fully programmable hand-held calculator with built-in magnetic card reader, it was used for course corrections on Apollo, and was introduced as "The Personal Computer" when keypunch machines were still the most common input device for mainframes.
While pricey, nearly $800 back in 1974, its quality and innovations garnered many enthusiasts, spawning clubs like the HP-65 Users Club and triggering medical recoveries (but that's another story!).
Thanks to Mike Dutch - Picture from Teclas.org
Gary Clouse reports: The early HP calculators were legendary for their durability. there were stories of them surviving 40 ft drops onto concrete, exposure to the weather for several months, and being run over by heavy eauipment on construction sites. The circuit board and battery contacts were gold-plated to prevent corrosion. There was a joke among engineering students that if there was a nuclear war, the survivors would be HP calculators and cockroaches.
computer.name: HP-65
computer.power: Battery pack containing 3x AA rechargeable cells
